description: Pontederia cordata, commonly known as pickerelweed, is an aquatic perennial with lance-shaped leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically cordate at the base and exhibit parallel venation. It produces spikes of lavender-blue flowers arranged in a dense, elongated cluster called a spike inflorescence.

Primula vulgaris, commonly called primrose, is a perennial herb with basal rosettes of elliptic leaves that have crenate margins. The leaves are typically pubescent and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces clusters of fragrant, five-petaled flowers in shades of yellow, white, or pink in early spring. The flowers are borne on short stalks rising from the center of the rosette.

Prunella vulgaris, commonly known as self-heal or heal-all, is a perennial herb with opposite, lanceolate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically pubescent and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces dense spikes of tubular, purple flowers with two lips in summer. The flowers are densely packed on the spike and attract pollinators.

Pulsatilla vulgaris, also known as pasqueflower, is a perennial herb with deeply dissected, fern-like leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are covered with fine hairs and exhibit palmate venation. It produces solitary, bell-shaped flowers with six petals in shades of purple, white, or pink. The flowers emerge in early spring and are followed by feathery seed heads.

Rhinanthus minor, commonly known as yellow rattle, is an annual herb with lanceolate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are arranged oppositely along the stem and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces yellow, two-lipped flowers with a distinctive inflated calyx in summer. The flowers are borne in terminal spikes.

Rudbeckia fulgida var. deamii, commonly known as orange coneflower, is a perennial herb with lanceolate to ovate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are usually pubescent and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces bright orange-yellow flowers with dark brown centers in late summer to early fall. The flowers are daisy-like and borne on stiff, hairy stems.

Salvia nemorosa, commonly known as woodland sage, is a perennial herb with ovate to lanceolate leaves that have entire to serrated margins. The leaves are typically gray-green and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces spikes of tubular flowers in shades of blue, purple, pink, or white in late spring to summer. The flowers are arranged in terminal inflorescences.

Hedera helix 'Goldheart', commonly known as goldheart ivy, is a woody vine with palmately lobed leaves that have a yellow-golden center and green margins. The leaves are typically glossy and exhibit palmate venation. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in late summer to early fall. The flowers are inconspicuous and arranged in umbels.

Alchemilla mollis, commonly known as lady's mantle, is a herbaceous perennial with circular, palmately lobed leaves that have finely serrated margins. The leaves are usually velvety and exhibit palmate venation. It produces small, chartreuse-yellow flowers in dense clusters in late spring to early summer. The flowers have no petals and are borne on erect stems.

Abelia x grandiflora, commonly known as glossy abelia, is a deciduous to semi-evergreen shrub with ovate to elliptic leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically glossy and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces clusters of tubular, fragrant flowers in shades of pink, white, or lavender from late spring to fall. The flowers are borne in terminal or axillary cymes.

Acanthus mollis, commonly known as bear's breeches, is a herbaceous perennial with deeply lobed, ovate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically glossy and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces tall spikes of tubular, white or purple flowers with purple bracts in summer. The flowers are borne in dense, terminal racemes.

Armeria maritima, commonly known as thrift or sea pink, is a compact, evergreen perennial with linear leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces dense, rounded clusters of small, pink, white, or red flowers on stiff stems in late spring to early summer. The flowers are borne in umbels.

Corylus avellana, commonly known as common hazel, is a deciduous shrub or small tree with rounded, serrated leaves. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces small, yellow-green catkins in late winter to early spring before the leaves emerge. The flowers are borne in clusters and are wind-pollinated.

Euphorbia characias subsp. wulfenii, commonly known as Mediterranean spurge, is a drought-tolerant perennial with linear, gray-green leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are arranged spirally along the stem and exhibit parallel venation. It produces tall spikes of lime-green flowers surrounded by chartreuse bracts in late spring to early summer. The flowers are borne in terminal cymes.

Metasequoia glyptostroboides, commonly known as dawn redwood, is a deciduous conifer with linear, flattened needles that have a fine, opposite arrangement. The needles exhibit parallel venation. It produces small, round cones in late summer to fall that mature to brown. The cones are borne on the branches and disintegrate to release seeds.

Miscanthus sinensis 'Zebrinus', commonly known as zebra grass, is a perennial grass with arching, green leaves that have horizontal, golden-yellow bands. The leaves are typically linear and exhibit parallel venation. It produces feathery, pinkish plumes in late summer to fall that rise above the foliage. The inflorescence is terminal and resembles a bottlebrush.

Stipa gigantea, commonly known as giant feather grass, is a clump-forming perennial grass with narrow, arching leaves that have finely serrated margins. The leaves are typically green and exhibit parallel venation. It produces tall, feathery panicles of golden-brown flowers in summer. The inflorescence is open and airy, adding movement to the landscape.

Symphyotrichum novi-belgii, commonly known as New York aster, is a herbaceous perennial with lanceolate leaves that have entire to serrated margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces clusters of daisy-like flowers with numerous violet-blue or pinkish rays surrounding yellow disk florets in late summer to fall. The flowers are borne in terminal corymbs.

Magnolia stellata, commonly known as star magnolia, is a deciduous shrub or small tree with ovate to elliptic leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces large, fragrant, star-shaped flowers with numerous white or pink tepals in early spring. The flowers are solitary or borne in small clusters.

Caltha palustris, commonly known as marsh marigold, is a herbaceous perennial with kidney-shaped leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit palmate venation. It produces bright yellow, bowl-shaped flowers in early spring. The flowers are borne singly on erect stems rising above the foliage.

Forsythia x intermedia, commonly known as border forsythia, is a deciduous shrub with ovate to lanceolate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically arranged oppositely along the stem and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces bright yellow, bell-shaped flowers in early spring before the leaves emerge. The flowers are borne profusely along the stems.

Lewisia cotyledon, commonly known as Siskiyou lewisia, is a herbaceous perennial with rosettes of linear to spatulate leaves that have entire to slightly toothed margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces showy, star-shaped flowers in shades of pink, red, orange, white, or yellow in late spring to early summer. The flowers are borne on slender stalks rising above the foliage.

Trachelospermum jasminoides, commonly known as star jasmine or Confederate jasmine, is a woody, evergreen vine with elliptic to ovate leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically glossy and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces small, white, star-shaped flowers with a sweet fragrance in late spring to summer. The flowers are borne in terminal cymes.

Typha angustifolia, commonly known as narrowleaf cattail, is a perennial aquatic plant with long, linear leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces cylindrical, brownish flower spikes in summer. The flower spikes are borne on erect stems and are densely packed with tiny, unisexual flowers.

Acer palmatum, commonly known as Japanese maple, is a deciduous tree with palmately lobed leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically arranged opposite and exhibit palmate venation. It produces inconspicuous, red to purple flowers in spring. The flowers are borne in small clusters, followed by winged samaras.

Betula pendula, commonly known as silver birch or European white birch, is a deciduous tree with triangular to diamond-shaped leaves that have doubly serrated margins. The leaves are typically arranged alternately and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces inconspicuous, yellow-brown catkins in spring before the leaves emerge. The catkins are pendulous and borne in clusters.

Iris pseudacorus, commonly known as yellow flag iris, is a rhizomatous perennial with linear, sword-shaped leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces large, yellow, iris-like flowers with six petals and yellow-orange markings in late spring to early summer. The flowers are borne on erect stems.

Centaurea cyanus, commonly known as bachelor's button or cornflower, is an annual or biennial herb with lanceolate leaves that have entire to slightly toothed margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces solitary, blue, pink, or white flowers with a prominent central disk in summer. The flowers are borne singly on slender stems.

Cotinus coggygria, commonly known as smoke tree or smoke bush, is a deciduous shrub or small tree with ovate to elliptic leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically arranged alternately and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces large, plume-like inflorescences called panicles in late spring to summer. The inflorescences are covered in tiny, hair-like filaments that give them a smoky appearance.

Fritillaria meleagris, commonly known as snake's head fritillary or chess flower, is a bulbous perennial with lanceolate leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit parallel venation. It produces nodding, bell-shaped flowers with checkered patterns in shades of purple, pink, or white in spring. The flowers are solitary or borne in umbels.

Ginkgo biloba, commonly known as ginkgo or maidenhair tree, is a deciduous tree with fan-shaped leaves that have parallel venation. The leaves are typically alternate and have entire margins. It produces inconspicuous, yellow-green flowers in spring. The flowers are dioecious, with male flowers borne in catkins and female flowers borne on short stalks.

Leucanthemum vulgare, commonly known as oxeye daisy, is a herbaceous perennial with lanceolate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces solitary, daisy-like flowers with white rays and yellow disk florets in late spring to summer. The flowers are borne on erect stems rising above the foliage.

Matteuccia struthiopteris, commonly known as ostrich fern, is a clump-forming perennial with upright, vase-shaped fronds that have deeply lobed, pinnate segments. The fronds are typically light green and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces spore-bearing structures called sori on the undersides of fertile fronds in summer. The sori are arranged in two rows on either side of the midrib.

Nigella damascena, commonly known as love-in-a-mist or devil in the bush, is an annual herb with finely dissected leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces solitary, pale blue, pink, or white flowers surrounded by a ruff of finely divided bracts in summer. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Phlomis fruticosa, commonly known as Jerusalem sage, is a drought-tolerant shrub with ovate to lanceolate leaves that have entire to serrated margins. The leaves are typically gray-green and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces whorls of tubular, yellow flowers with woolly calyces in late spring to summer. The flowers are borne in terminal clusters.

Wisteria sinensis, commonly known as Chinese wisteria, is a woody, deciduous vine with pinnately compound leaves that have entire leaflets. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces cascading clusters of fragrant, pea-like flowers in shades of lavender, purple, or white in late spring to early summer. The flowers are borne on racemes.

Lavandula angustifolia, commonly known as English lavender, is a fragrant, woody perennial with linear leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically gray-green and exhibit parallel venation. It produces spikes of small, fragrant, purple-blue flowers in summer. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Achillea millefolium, commonly known as yarrow, is a herbaceous perennial with fern-like leaves that have finely dissected segments and entire margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces flat-topped clusters of tiny, white, pink, or yellow flowers in summer. The flowers are borne on erect stems rising above the foliage.

Astrantia major 'Hadspen's Blood', commonly known as masterwort, is a herbaceous perennial with deeply lobed, palmate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit palmate venation. It produces umbels of small, domed flowers surrounded by showy bracts in shades of deep red to maroon in summer. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Campsis radicans 'Flava', commonly known as yellow trumpet vine, is a vigorous, woody vine with pinnately compound leaves that have serrated leaflets. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces large, trumpet-shaped flowers in shades of yellow to orange in summer to fall. The flowers are borne in terminal racemes.

Cosmos bipinnatus, commonly known as garden cosmos, is an annual herb with finely dissected leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces solitary, daisy-like flowers with pink, red, or white rays and yellow disk florets in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Dahlia 'Bishop of Llandaff' is a cultivar of Dahlia, a herbaceous perennial with pinnately compound leaves that have toothed margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces large, semi-double to double flowers with deep red petals and dark centers in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on sturdy stems rising above the foliage.

Daucus carota, commonly known as wild carrot or Queen Anne's lace, is a biennial herb with finely dissected leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces flat-topped clusters of tiny, white flowers surrounded by showy bracts in summer. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Corydalis flexuosa, commonly known as Chinese fumewort, is a herbaceous perennial with finely divided leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces racemes of spurred, tubular flowers in shades of pink, lavender, or white in spring to early summer. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Fagus sylvatica, commonly known as European beech, is a deciduous tree with ovate to elliptic leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces inconspicuous, yellow-green flowers in spring. The flowers are borne in catkins.

Canna indica, commonly known as Indian shot or Canna lily, is a rhizomatous perennial with large, paddle-shaped leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically arranged alternately and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces spikes of showy, iris-like flowers in shades of red, orange, yellow, or pink in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on tall stems rising above the foliage.

Crataegus monogyna, commonly known as common hawthorn or single-seeded hawthorn, is a deciduous shrub or small tree with lobed leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces clusters of white, five-petaled flowers in late spring to early summer. The flowers are borne in terminal corymbs.

Echinacea purpurea 'Alba', commonly known as white coneflower, is a herbaceous perennial with lanceolate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically basal and exhibit parallel venation. It produces large, daisy-like flowers with white rays and orange-brown disk florets in summer. The flowers are borne singly on erect stems.

Eryngium giganteum 'Silver Ghost', commonly known as giant sea holly, is a herbaceous perennial with basal rosettes of spiny, silver-gray leaves that have entire to toothed margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit parallel venation. It produces spiky, steel-blue flower heads surrounded by silvery bracts in summer. The flowers are borne on sturdy stems rising above the foliage.

Heliotropium arborescens, commonly known as garden heliotrope or cherry pie plant, is an aromatic perennial with ovate to lanceolate leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically arranged alternately and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces dense clusters of small, fragrant, purple flowers in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on erect stems.

Lobelia cardinalis, commonly known as cardinal flower, is a herbaceous perennial with lanceolate to ovate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically arranged alternately and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces spikes of tubular, scarlet-red flowers in summer to early fall. The flowers are borne on tall stems rising above the foliage.

Lonicera periclymenum 'Serotina', commonly known as late Dutch honeysuckle or woodbine, is a twining, deciduous vine with ovate to elliptic leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically arranged oppositely and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces fragrant, tubular flowers with white to pink or red outer petals and yellow throats in summer to fall. The flowers are borne in terminal whorls.

Oenothera biennis, commonly known as evening primrose, is a biennial herb with lanceolate to oblanceolate leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically alternate and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces solitary, yellow, four-petaled flowers that open in the evening in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.

Phlox paniculata, commonly known as garden phlox, is a herbaceous perennial with lanceolate leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically arranged oppositely and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces dense panicles of fragrant, five-petaled flowers in shades of pink, purple, white, or red in summer. The flowers are borne on sturdy stems rising above the foliage.

Tagetes erecta, commonly known as African marigold or American marigold, is an annual herb with pinnately dissected leaves that have entire margins. The leaves are typically arranged alternately and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces solitary, daisy-like flowers with yellow to orange rays and yellow disk florets in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on erect stems.

Verbena bonariensis, commonly known as tall verbena or purpletop vervain, is a herbaceous perennial with lanceolate leaves that have serrated margins. The leaves are typically arranged oppositely and exhibit pinnate venation. It produces clusters of small, fragrant, purple flowers in summer to fall. The flowers are borne on slender stems rising above the foliage.
